Award.AwardTitle: INSPIRE Track 1: Interdisciplinary Approach to Discovery, Analyses and Applications of Informative Ancient Biomolecules
Award.AbstractNarration:
Interdisciplinary Approach to Discovery, Analyses and Applications of Informative Ancient Biomolecules

Mary Schweitzer
North Carolina State University

This INSPIRE award is partially funded by Sedimentary Geology and Paleobiology Program and Surface Earth Processes Section of the Earth Science Division of the Directorate for Geoscience, the Genetic Mechanisms Cluster of the Directorate for Biosciences, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program of the Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences, the Cross-EF Activities Program, the Office of Multidisciplinary Activities, and the INSPIRE program.

Conventional wisdom states there is a short (>1 million years) ?life span? for original molecules. Recent recovery of both soft tissues (blood vessels and their contents, cells, flexible matrix), and component molecules indicates that under some conditions, tissues and the molecules comprising them will persist longer than proposed. During the tenure of this project, the researchers hope to demonstrate that biomolecules recovered from ancient fossils can yield information on evolutionary relationships, as well as other aspects of extinct organisms. More importantly perhaps, they will study the chemical nature of modifications to these original molecules that contribute to preservation, such as unusual cross links, or bonding to environmental chemicals; and will study which environments are most likely to yield fossils preserving this kind of information, which will benefit the field at large, because a better understanding of process and environment will expand molecular studies of fossils.

The proposed time limit on molecular preservation has limited testing of older fossils for molecular content and hindered methods development. Molecules, especially DNA and proteins, yield information on evolution, but also on the function of organisms, and perhaps on how evolution and natural selection work at the molecular level. But, to undertake this research requires an expansion of existing databases which are used for comparison. Currently, the vast majority of genomic and proteomic data are derived from humans, next from mammals. The researchers propose to generate proteomic data from non-mammalian taxa as part of this project. Additionally, existing databases do not account for modifications to molecules due to preservational processes, and thus many search algorithms will fail to identify modified molecules. The researchers will address this by conducting time-point sampling of a single taxon, and by experiments designed to approximate the natural processes that may result in molecular preservation.
To understand the evolution of life, scientists have relied on morphological characters retained in fossilized elements, and both morphological and molecular data derived from extant organisms. However, in some cases, molecular studies give a different picture of evolutionary histories than do morphological features, and when these conflict, relationships are not clear. This research challenges the conventional wisdom of ~1Ma temporal limits of molecular longevity, and has the potential to extend the record of molecular evolution into deep time.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For this project, we proposed to demonstrate that original biomolecules (e.g., proteins) could persist in fossilized remains millions of years old using a host of analytical tools, and to develop and employ methods that would enable other investigators to rigorously analyze fossil materials at the molecular level. This approach to paleontological research challenges convention wisdom that molecules have a “time limit” for preservation, and we showed that, instead, in select environments these molecules can persist. We additionally demonstrated that recovered molecules can be used to investigate questions ranging from evolutionary relationships to origins of evolutionary novelties like feathers. We also compared existing extraction and analytical methods applied to both fossils and extant material, that extraction procedures can be optimized to recover more, and more diverse, endogenous molecules. Our research reached across the purview of several divisions within the NSF, illustrating the importance of a focused, multidisciplinary approach to recovering and analyzing data from fossils.

For centuries, our knowledge of organisms that once populated our planet was limited to the morphology (shape) of tissues that fossilized. This was in large part because of the reigning assumption that morphology is all that preserves, and the molecules originally comprising these tissues are totally lost shortly after death.  Thus, although the study of living organisms has expanded to include, and is now based largely upon, protein and DNA studies, researchers have been slow to apply these same methods to fossilized remains of extinct organisms (beyond those very recently extinct, such as the dodo). Yet, evolution occurs first at the molecular level, and changes are only later reflected in things we can see and measure; thus, this lack of molecular data for extinct species presents a large gap in our understanding of life on this planet.

Intellectual Merit: Our studies have not only contributed to understanding how molecules degrade (and alternatively, why they do not), but have also pushed the limits of analytical tools and techniques. We have expanded comparative databases, and optimized extraction and analytical methods for recovery of these ancient molecular remains. We have recovered sequence data from many proteins within these ancient materials, including collagen, actin, and histone proteins, and showed that these results are repeatable. As a result, the first dinosaur proteomes were greatly expanded with new data and new analytical tools. In addition, we have applied a host of antibodies directly to ancient tissues to demonstrate that molecules preserve over time, by showing antibody binding patterns that are similar to modern tissues of the same type. We also showed that antibodies can be used to differentiate multiple tissues within a single specimen. These efforts have resulted in 24 peer reviewed publications and 4 in progress, 5 awarded PhDs and one in progress, as well as 2 MS degrees and one in progress. We have also established many international (University of Lund, Sweden; University of Copenhagen, Denmark; IVPP and Nanjing Institute of Paleontology and Geology, China; University of Alberta, Canada); and national (Rowan University, Montana State University, Tourism and Culture division, Yukon,  and University of California Museum of Paleontology, Berkeley) collaborations, that provide students with varied research opportunities and access to samples.

Broader impacts: In the age of renewed public interest in the Jurassic Park franchise, the results of our studies have captured the attention and imagination of the public. Our lab has a strong focus on outreach, and we have used the funded research as a means to engage with professional audiences, the general public, and students. This has included media interviews (e.g., Quirks & Quarks, Live Science, Science 360) and media coverage (e.g., Science Magazine, Washington Post, Science News, Forbes, Huffington Post), as well as invited talks and a variety of public and professional events, both national and international. Public outreach venues include Dinofest Los Angeles County and Cleveland Museums, The Burke Museum (Seattle); Biologos featured speaker, and many others. In addition, our research has been the focus of invited professional presentations, including Plenary talks at Human Proteome Organization, Swedish Chemical Society, Evolution in Sweden, and the Ancient Proteomics Conference in Denmark, among others.

This NSF-funded research has also, in part, formed the basis for an undergraduate textbook that teaches students how to approach scientific topics through the lens of dinosaur science—that uses the question “How do we know what we know about dinosaurs?” as a framework for exploring how we ask and answer questions about things we cannot directly observe. The contract for this book and its learning materials has already been signed to a publisher.
